word_definition: To choose not to consume.  To choose not to take part
word_example: Considered a health nut, she abstained from anything containing sugar.

word_definition: Bitterness and ill will.
word_example: The acrimony between the president and vice-president sent a clear signal to voters.  The health of the current administration was imperiled.

word_definition: One who professes sensitivity to beauty of art and nature.
word_example: As a true aesthete, he would spend hours a the museum, staring at the same painting.

word_definition: Concerned with the appreciation of beauty.  A set of principles underlying the guiding the work of a particular artist or artistic movement.
word_example: The artist operated according to a peculiar aesthetic, not considering any photograph t be worth publishing unless it contained a marine mammal.

word_definition: A mixture of multiple things.
word_example: The band''s music was an amalgam of hiphop, flamenco, and jazz.  The bleinding of the three styles had surprising results.

word_definition: Open to more than one interpretation.
word_example: The coach told his team:  ''Move towards that side of the field.''  Because he did not point, his directions were ambiguous.  The team had no idea to which side he was referring.

word_definition: Mixed or conflicting emotions about something.
word_example: Sam was ambivalent about studying for the exam because doing so ate up a lot of his time.  Yet he was able to improve his analytical skills.

word_definition: Make something bad better.
word_example: This is a story of a western man who hopes to ameliorate poverty and lack of education in a foreign country.

word_definition: Easily persuaded.
word_example: Even though she did not like the outdoors, Shirley was generally amenable and so her brother was able to persuade her to go camping.

word_definition: Shapeless.
word_example: His study plan for the GRE was at best amorphous.  He would do questions from random pages in any one of seven test preparation books.

word_definition: Not normal.
word_example: According to those who do not believe in climate change, the extreme weather over the last five years is simply anomalous.

word_definition: Characterized by a lack of interest.
word_example: He was so talented at teaching math that even normally apathetic students took interest.

word_definition: An absence of emotion.  An absence of enthusiasm.
word_example: Widespread apathy among voters led to a very small turnout on election day.

word_definition: Clever in a cunning way.
word_example: Bernie Madoff's artful Ponzi scheme stole billions of dollars from investors and is considered the largest financial fraud in United States history.

word_definition: Practicing self-denial.
word_example: His ascetic life is the main reason he inspired to many followers, especially since he gave up wealth and power to live in poverty.

word_definition: Willing to be bold in social situations.  To take risks.
word_example: As all of the other campers cowered in their tents, Bill audaciously tracked down the bear that had raided their food.

word_definition: Favorable.
word_example: Despite an auspicious beginning, Mike''s road trip became a series of mishaps.  He was soon stranded and penniless, leaning against his wrecked automobile.

word_definition: Excessively greedy.
word_example: Since avaricious desire is similar to gluttony or lust, it was listed as one of the seven deadly sins by the Catholic church.

word_definition: Repeated too often.  Over familiar through over use.
word_example: The professor used such banal expressions that many of the students fell asleep from boredom.

word_definition: Misrepresent.
word_example: The simile on here face belies the pain she must feel after the death of her husband.

word_definition: Characteristic of one eager to fight.
word_example: He said that he was arguing the matter purely for philosophical reasons, but his belligerent tone indicated an underlying anger about the issue.

word_definition: To unintentionally reval something.
word_example: With the gold medal at stake, the gymnast awaited his turn.  His quivering lip betraying his intense emotions.

word_definition: Relating to the pleasant aspects of the country.
word_example: The noble families of England once owned vast expanses of beautiful, bucolic land.

word_definition: Making of a false statement meant to injure a person's reputation.
word_example: With the presidential primaries well under way, the air is thick with calumny with the mud already waist-high.

word_definition: To reprimand harshly.
word_example: Drill sergeants are known to castigate new recurits to mercilessly that the latter often break down during their first week in training.

word_definition: To express strong disapproval.
word_example: After being caught in bed with a mistress, the mayor was quickly censured by the city council.

word_definition: To reprimand harshly.
word_example: Though chastised for eating the snacks for the party, Lawrence shrugged off his mother''s harsh words and continued to plow through jars of cookies and boxes of doughnuts.

word_definition: Muffled laughter.
word_example: Walking INTO the cafe, I could hear happy, chortling people and sell the rich aroma of roasted coffee beans.

word_definition: To cleverly find a way out of duties or obligations.
word_example: One way of circumventing the GRE is to apply to a grad school that does not require GRE scores.

word_definition: To be in proportion or corresponding in degree or amount.
word_example: The convicted felon's life sentence was commensurate with the heinousness of his crime.

word_definition: To acknowledge defeat.  To admit wrongdoing.  To give over; surrender or relinquish to the physical control of another.
word_example: I concede.  You win!  After a long, stern lecture from her father, Olivia conceded to having broken the window.  The Spanish were forced to concede much of the territory.

word_definition: Completely obvious.  Withou any attempt at concealment.
word_example: American basketball players are always conspicuous when they go abroad.  Not only are they American, but some are over seven feet tall.

word_definition: To pull off a scheme through trickery.
word_example: Despite a low GPA, he contrived to get into college, going so far as to write his own glowing letters of recommendation.

word_definition: Intentionally vague.
word_example: Since Sarah did not want her husband to guess the Christmas present she had bought him, she only answered cryptically when he would ask her questions about it.

word_definition: To reach the highest or most decisive point.
word_example: Beethoven''s musical genius culminated in the 9th Symphony, which many consider his greatest work.

word_definition: A state of guilt.
word_example: Since John had left his banana peel at the top of the stairwell, he accepted culpability for Martha''s broken leg.

word_definition: Characterized by good taste in manners and conduct.
word_example: Sally's parties are decorous affairs of tea and intellectual conversations.

word_definition: Show respect.
word_example: If you ever have the chance to meet the president, stand up straight and be deferential.

word_definition: To describe in detail.
word_example: After a brief summary of the marketing plan, the manager delineated the specifics of each campaign.

word_definition: Show reluctance.  To object.
word_example: Wallace disliked the cold, so he demurred when his friends suggested they go skiing in the Alps.

word_definition: A sign or indication of some meaning.
word_example: Even if the text is not visible, the red octagon denotes stop to all motorists in America.

word_definition: Not original but drawing strongly on something already in existence.  Especially in reference to a creative product such as music, writing, and science.
word_example: Because the movies were utterly derivative of other popular movies, they did well at the box office.

word_definition: Reason by deduction.
word_example: From the multiple set of footprints in the living room, the investigator derived an important clue.

word_definition: Expecting unquestioning obedience.  Characteristic of an absolute ruler.
word_example: The coach was dictatorial in his approach.  No player could ever argue or question his approach.

word_definition: Instructive to excess.
word_example: Tolstoy's 'The Death of Ivan Ilyich' is a didactic novel.  It instructs the reader on how to live a good life.

word_definition: Lacking self-confidence.  Show modest reserve.
word_example: As a young girl she was diffident and reserved.  Now, as an adult, she is confident and assertive.

word_definition: To be discontented as toward authority.
word_example: After watching his superior take rations fro the soldiers, he quickly became disaffected and rebelled.

word_definition: Unbiased.  Neutral.
word_example: The potential juror knew the defendant and therefore could not serve on the jury, which must consist only of disinterested members.

word_definition: Highly opinionated.  Not accepting that your belief may not be correct.
word_example: Bryan is dogmatic in his belief that the earth is flat, claiming that all pictures of a spherical earth are computer generated.

word_definition: Comprised of a variety of styles.
word_example: He was known for his eclectic tastes in music.  One moment dancing to disco and next conducting Beethoven's 9th Symphony.

word_definition: Standing out in a negative way.  Shockingly bad.
word_example: The dictator's abuse of human rights was so egregious that many world leaders demanded that he be tried in an international court for genocide.

word_definition: To make clearer and easier to understand.
word_example: You Tube is a great place to learn just about anything.  An expert elucidates finer points so that even a complete novice can learn.

word_definition: Standing above others in quality or position.
word_example: Shakespeare is an eminent author in the English language, but I find his writing uninteresting and melodramatic.

word_definition: To sap energy from someone.
word_example: John preferred to avoid equatorial countries.  The intense sun would always leave him enervated after he had spent the day sightseeing.

word_definition: To give rise to something.
word_example: The restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles were so severe that they engendered deep hatred and resentment in the German people.

word_definition: Fixed firmly or securely.
word_example: By the time we reach 60 years of age, must of our habits are so entrenched that it is difficult for us to change.

word_definition: Last a very short time.
word_example: The lifespan of a mayfly is ephemeral, lasting from a few hours to a couple days.

word_definition: Confusing or ambiguous.
word_example: The findings of the study wee equivocal.  The two researchers had different opinions on what the results signified.

word_definition: To avoid.  To stay away from something.
word_example: He eschew the question.

word_definition: To make worse.
word_example: Her sleeplessness exacerbated her cold.

word_definition: Still in existence.  Usually refers to documents.
word_example: Despite many bookstores closing, experts predict that some for of book dealing will still be extant generations from now.

word_definition: A belief that is based on faulty reasoning.
word_example: The widespread belief that Eskimos have forty different words for snow is fallacious, based on one false report.

word_definition: Characterized by hopelessness.
word_example: After the third pet dog died, she was simply forlorn.  This time even the possibility of buying a new dog no longer held any joy.

word_definition: Occurring my happy chance.  Having no apparent cause.
word_example: Though her neighbor bumped into her at the market, the encounter was not a fortuitous as she was led to believe.  He wanted to ask her our on a date and had been following her about town.

word_definition: Not serious in content, attitude, or behavior.
word_example: Compared too Juliet''s passionate concern for human rights, Jake''s non-stop concern about football seems somewhat frivolous.

word_definition: Spending money wisely.
word_example: Monte was no miser.  He was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.

word_definition: To hinder or prevent.  Especially regarding efforts, plans, or desires.
word_example: I thought I would finish writing the paper by noon, but a number of urgent interruptions served to frustrate my plan.

word_definition: To deny or contradict.  To speak against or oppose.
word_example: I cannot gainsay a single piece of evidence, but I still do not trust his conclusion.

word_definition: Being rude and impertinent.  Feeling of deep and bitter anger and ill will.
word_example: In an act of gall, Leah sent compromising photos of here ex-boyfriend to all of his co-workers and professional contacts.

word_definition: To excite or inspre someone to action.
word_example: At mile 23 of his first marathon, Kyle had all but given up.  Then he noticed his friends and family holding a banner that read ''Go Kyle''.  Galvanized, he broke INTO a gallop, finishing the last three miles in less than 20 minutes.

word_definition: Relevant.  Appropriate.
word_example: The professor wanted to tell the jury in detail about his new book.  However, the lawyer said it was not germane to the charges in the case.

word_definition: An excessive supply.  To supply with an excessive amount.
word_example: In the middle of economic crises, hiring managers find their inboxes glutted with resumes.

word_definition: Characterized by unusual lightness and delicacy.
word_example: The gossamer wings of a butterfly enable it to fly. However, they are also a curse because they are so delicate that they are often damaged.

word_definition: To socialize with others.
word_example: Often we think that great leaders are those who are gregarious, always in the middle of a large group of people.  Ye, as Mahatma Gandhi has shown us, a leader can also be introverted.

word_definition: Free of deceit.
word_example: At first I thought my niece was guileless, but then I found myself buying her ice cream every time we passed a shop.

word_definition: To deliver a long pompous speech or tirate.
word_example: Tired of his parents haranguing him about his laziness, Tyler finally moved out of home at the age of thirty-five.

word_definition: Showing arrogant disdain to those ones views as unworthy.
word_example: The haughty manager did not believe that any of his subordinates could ever have an insight as brilliant as his own.

word_definition: A person who holds unorthodox opinions in any field.
word_example: Though everyone at the gym told him to do cardio before weights, he was a heretic and always did the reverse.

word_definition: Someone who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions.
word_example: Lady Gaga, in challenging what is means to be clothed, is an iconoclast for wearing a ''meat dress'' to a prominent awards show.

word_definition: Cannot be changed.
word_example: Taxes are one of the immutable laws of the land, so there is no use arguing about paying them.

word_definition: Being disrepectful.  Improperly forward or bold.
word_example: Dexter, distraught over losing his pet dachshund, Madeline, found the police officer''s question impertinent.  She did not have to pry INTO such details as to what Madeline''s favorite snack was.

word_definition: Improperly forward or bold.
word_example: In an impudent act, the defendant spoke out of order to say terribly insulting things to the judge.

word_definition: The ability to recognize fine distinctions.
word_example: The lawyer had an incisive mind, able to dissect a tangled issue and isolate the essential laws at play.

word_definition: Lacking in harmony.  Lacking in compatibility or appropriateness
word_example: The vast economic inequality of modern society is incongruous with America's ideals.

word_definition: Impossible to stop or prevent.
word_example: The rise of the computer was n inexorable shift in technology and culture.

word_definition: To be naive and innocent.
word_example: Two years in Manhattan had changed Jenna from an ingenuous girl from the suburbs to a jaded urbanite, unlikely to fall for any ruse, regardless of how elaborate.

word_definition: Harmless.  Does not produce any ill effects.
word_example: Everyone found Nancy''s banter innocuous.  Mike, however, felt like she was intentionally picking on him.

word_definition: Working in a subtle, destructive way.
word_example: Plaque is insidious.  We cannot see it, but each day it eats away at our enamel, causing cavities and other dental problems.

word_definition: To suggest something subtly.
word_example: At first Manfred''s teachers intimated to his parents that he was not suited to skip a grade.  When his parents protested, the teachers explicitly told him that, not withstanding the boy''s precocity, he was simply was simply to immature to jump to the sixth grade.

word_definition: Complicated.  Difficult to comprehend.
word_example: The physics lecture became to involved that the undergraduate's eyes glazed over.

word_definition: Traveling from place to place to work.
word_example: Doctors used to be itinerant, traveling between patients'' homes.

word_definition: Fanatical patriotism.
word_example: North Korea maintains intense control over its population through a combination of jingoism and cult of personality.

word_definition: Full of delight because of success.
word_example: My hard work paid off and I was jubilant to receive a perfect score on the GRE.

word_definition: To place side by side for contrast.
word_example: The appeal of her paintings comes from a classical style which is juxtaposed with modern themes.

word_definition: A writing, speech, or person of few words.
word_example: The laconic paper was a single page.

word_definition: To criticize severely.  To criticize angrily.
word_example: Showing no patience, the manager lambasted the sales team that lost the big account.

word_definition: Slow and relaxed.  Not inclined towards physical exertion or effort.
word_example: As the sun beat down and the temperature climbed higher, we spent a languid week lying around the house.

word_definition: Noble an generous in spirit.  Especially towards a rival or someone less powerful.
word_example: He was a great sportsman.  In defeat he was complimentary and in victory he was magnanimous.

word_definition: To assert.
word_example: The scientist maintained that the extinction of dinosaours was likely brought about by the drastic change in climate.

word_definition: Overly sentimental to the point that it is disgusting.
word_example: The film was incredibly mawkish.  It introduced highly likeable characters only to have them succumb to a devastating illness by the end of the movie.

word_definition: Prone to unexpected and unpredictable changes in mood.  Refers to a person.
word_example: The fact that Ella's moods were as mercurial as the weather was problematic for her relationships.  It did not help that she lived in Chicago.

word_definition: Characterized by extreme care in treatment of details.
word_example: The noodle maker was meticulous in making noodles and would never let another person take over the task.

word_definition: Lessen the severity of an offense.
word_example: If it were not for the mitigating circumstances, he would have certainly lost his job.

word_definition: To make an angry person less angry.  Placate.
word_example: In the morning, she was unable to mollify him, if he happened to become angry, unless he had his cup of coffee.

word_definition: So small as to be meaningless.  Insignificant.
word_example: The GRE tests cumulative knowledge.  So if  you cram the night before it is, at best, likely to only have a negligible impact on your score.

word_definition: Known by only a few.
word_example: Many of the biggest movie stars were once obscure actors who got only bit roles in long forgotten films.

word_definition: Distinctive and showy elegance.
word_example: He, with his typical panache, came to the wedding reception with a top hat and cane.

word_definition: Narrowly restricted in scope or outlook.
word_example: Jasmine was sad to admit it, but her fledgling relationship with Jacob did not work out because his culinary tastes were simply too parochial.  ''After all,'' she quipped on her blog, ''he considered Chef Boyardee ethnic food.''

word_definition: Extremely frugal.  Miserly.
word_example: Katie is so parsimonious that she only buys a pair of socks if all of here other socks have holes in them.

word_definition: An act of deliberate betrayal.  A breach of trust.
word_example: Sure, he was the best salesman in the company.  However, Michael had abused the trust of the firm.  He shared product secrets with a competitor.  For such perfidy he was terminated.

word_definition: A trite or obvious remark.
word_example: The professor argued that many statements regard as wise in previous times, such as the Golden Rule, are now regarded as mere platitudes.

word_definition: To keep from happening.  To make impossible.
word_example: The manager specified that all other gates be locked, to preclude the possibility of persons without tickets entering the area.

word_definition: Characterized by early maturity.  Especially in mental aptitude.
word_example: Though only seven years old, she was a precocious chess prodigy, able to beat players twice her age.

word_definition: A strong liking to something.
word_example: Monte had a predilection for the fine things in life.

word_definition: The power to foresee the future.
word_example: Baxter's warnings about investing in technology stocks seemed like an act of prescience after the whole market declined significantly.

word_definition: To speak in an evasive way.
word_example: The cynic quipped, ''There is not much variance in politicians.  They all seem to prevaricate''.

word_definition: Rashly or watefully extravagant.
word_example: Successful professional athletes who do not fall prey to prodigality seem tobe the exception.  Most live decadent lives.

word_definition: Some one who spends resources recklessly.
word_example: Most lottery winners go from being parsimonious types to toutright profligates who blow millions on fast cars, lavish homes, and giant yachts.

word_definition: To make less severe.  To limit, usually in a statement.
word_example: Chris qualified his love for San Francisco, adding he did not like the weather there as much as he liked the weather in Los Angeles.

word_definition: Habitually complaining.
word_example: The querulous old woman was beginning o wear down even the happier members of the staff with here ceaseless complaining.

word_definition: Found in the ordinary course of events.
word_example: He gets so involved thinking about Aristotle''s arguments that he totally forgets quotidian concerns, such a exercising and eating regularly.

word_definition: Difficult to comprehend.
word_example: I found Ulysses recondite and never finished the book.  I am waiting to read it with someone else so we could penetrate its meaning together.

word_definition: Resistant to authority.  Resistant to control.
word_example: Accustomed to studious high school students, she was unprepared for the refractory kindergartners who neither sat still nor listen to a single word she said.

word_definition: Restless.
word_example: The crowd grew restive as the comedian's opening jokes fell flat.

word_definition: Reluctant to talk.  Not revealing thoughts.
word_example: When asked about her father, Helen lost here outward enthusiasm and became rather eticent.

word_definition: Being in the earliest states of development.  Involving basic facts or principles.
word_example: I would love to be able to present a fully polished proposal to the board.  However, our plans for the product are still in the most rudimentary stages.

word_definition: Characteristic of rural life.  Awkwardly simple and provincial.
word_example: The vacation cabin had no electricity and no indoor plumbing.  Despite these inconveniences, Nigel adored its rustic charm.

word_definition: Something plausible but false.
word_example: When listening to a politician speak, it is hard to distinguish the spurious claims from the authentic ones.

word_definition: Dependable loyalty.
word_example: No longer a staunch supporter of the movement he now will openly question whether its goals are worthwhile.

word_definition: To contain or include.
word_example: The rogue wave quickly subsumed the pier.  The novel subsumes all other novels, demonstrating modern literary devices.

word_definition: more than is needed, desired, or required.
word_example: The third paragraph in your essay is superfluous and can be deleted.

word_definition: To take the place of something  To move into the position of something.
word_example: For many, a cellular telephone has supplanted the traditional telephone.  In fact, most twenty-year-olds do not have a traditional telephone.

word_definition: Essentially being equal to something.
word_example: In many situations, remaining silent is tantamount to admitting guilt, so speak to prove your innocence.

word_definition: Unyielding.
word_example: Even the most tenacious advocates for gun ownership must admit some of the dangers that firearms present.

word_definition: Inactivity resulting from lethargy.
word_example: After work, I was expecting my colleagues to be enthusiastic about the outing.  However, I found them in a state of complete torpor.

word_definition: An absurd presentation of something.  A mockery.
word_example: What I expected to be an intelligent, nuanced historical documentary turned out to be a poorly-produced travesty of the form.

word_definition: Tending to betray.  Dangerously unstable and unpredictable.
word_example: The bridge built from twine and vine is treacherous to walk across.

word_definition: To weaken.  Usually paired with an abstract term.
word_example: The student undermined the teacher's authority by questioning the teacher's judgment on numerous occasions.

word_definition: Having only one meaning or interpretation and leading to only one conclusion.
word_example: The President''s first statement on the subject was vague and open to competing interpretations.  When he spoke to Congress about the same subject later, hes was careful to make his position completely unequivocal.

word_definition: To scold.  To reproach.
word_example: Bob took a risk walking INTO the Students Barbershop.  In the end he had to upbraid the apparently drunk barber for giving him an uneven bowl cut.

word_definition: Marked by extreme intensity of emotions.
word_example: While the other employees responded to the bad news in a measured way, he responded in a vehement manner, tipping over his desk and shouting at the top of his lungs.

word_definition: The condition of being suscptible to bribes or corruption.
word_example: Even some of the most sacred sporting events are not immune to venality.  Many of the officials have received substantial bribes to make biased calls.

word_definition: To respect deeply.
word_example: The professor, despite his sleep-inducing lectures, was venerated amongst his colleagues, publishing more papers yearly than al of his peers combined.

word_definition: Truthful.
word_example: While we elect our leaders in the hope that every word they speak will be veracious, history has shown that such a hope is naive.

word_definition: To spread negative information about a person.
word_example: He was noble after the divorce, choosing to say only complimentary things about here.  However, she did not hesitate to vilify him.

word_definition: To clear of accusation.  Done with supporting arguments or proof.
word_example: Even seven Tour de France wins cannot vindicate Lance Armstring in the eyes of the public.

word_definition: Conspicuously and offensively loud.  Given to vehement outcry.
word_example: In giving her a vociferous response, he caused people at every other table to turn around and look at them angrily

word_definition: The quality of talking or writing easily and continuously.
word_example: The professor's volubility knows no bounds.  He could talk through a hurricane and elaborate a point from one St. Patrick's Day to the next.

word_definition: Lacking.
word_example: She did not think here vocabulary was wanting.  However, there were so many words that inevitably she found a few she did not know.
